title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Identification Error

Another reason why we might see that result, i.e.Â if the same result could give us a different conclusion, like kids who are aggressive play more video games or people notice aggression more when kids play video games, then
we have made an identification error* - our result was not identified!*
Identification error is when your result in the data doesnâ€™t actually have a clear theory (â€œwhyâ€ or â€œbecauseâ€)
For example, if you observe that people tend to wear more shorts on days they eat more ice cream, and you conclude that eating ice cream makes you put on shorts

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text: Data Generating Process

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Data Generating Process

The prices that we observe come from that theoretical construct
When we see the prices and quantities moving, according to our theory, it is because the S and D lines are moving
But we cannot see the S and D lines
Our goal: use the observations we do see to infer what the theoretical model (data generating process) is

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Data Generating Process

Harder than it sounds. What inference about S and D can we draw from these observations?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Causality

A data generating process can be described by a series of equations that describe where the data comes from. For example:

\[ X = \gamma_0 + \gamma_1\varepsilon + \nu \]
\[ Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \varepsilon \]

This says â€ \(X\) is caused by \(\varepsilon\) and \(\nu\), and \(Y\) is caused by \(X\) and \(\varepsilon\)â€
The truth is that an increase in \(X\) causally increases \(Y\) by \(\beta_1\)
The goal of econometrics is to be able to estimate what \(\beta_1\) is accurately

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Causality

We can also represent this set of relationships as a graph, with arrows telling you what variables cause each other

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Causality

We do this because most of the relationships weâ€™re interested in are causal - we want to know, if we could reach in and manipulate \(X\), would \(Y\) change as a result, and how much?
Does the minimum wage reduce employment?
Does quantitative easing avert recessions?
Does six-sigma improve business performance?
Does getting an MBA make you a better manager?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Causality

Imagine this is the graph we see for minimum wage and employment

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Causality

A given correlation, like the negative relationship between minimum wage changes and employment changes, can be consistent with a number of different causal relationships
As econometricians, we need to figure out which one it is!
How can we narrow it down?
How many of the diagrams on the next page can be consistent with that negative relationship?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text: Eight Possible Relationships

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Causality

The only ones we can eliminate are d, g, and h
All the rest are possible!
If f is correct, we see the negative relationship even though minimum wage has nothing to do with causing employment (like the ice cream and shorts example)
If a is correct, then even though we know minimum wage causes employment to change, the size or even direction of the relationship will be wrong (why?)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Causality

So which of them is likely to be correct?
That depends on what we think \(\varepsilon\) is
\(\varepsilon\) is everything that determines \(Y\) other than \(X\)
Perhaps the health of the economy, or the policies that area has chosen
So we almost certainly have a graph with \(\varepsilon \rightarrow Y\)
Do those things also affect the choice to raise the minimum wage? If so weâ€™re in graph a. That downward relationship could be due to a null relationship, or even a positive one (or perhaps a more negative one?)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Endogeneity

So â€œcorrelation isnâ€™t causationâ€ isnâ€™t quite complete
Itâ€™s more â€œonly certain correlations are causalâ€
Many correlations are beset by these problems like endogeneity, i.e.Â the presence of another variable like \(\varepsilon\) related to both \(X\) and \(Y\), giving the effect a â€œback doorâ€
So the correlation reflects both the causal effect and also the influence of \(\varepsilon\)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Random Experiments

For this reason, random experiments are generally considered the â€œgold standardâ€
Although they have their own problems, of course (your experimental sample might not represent the population well, there are plenty of statistical mistakes to make, people may act differently knowing theyâ€™re in an experiment, etc. etc.)
But regardless, weâ€™re looking here at questions for which we canâ€™t run an experiment, becuase itâ€™s impossible or infeasible or immoral
So one way we can think about solving this endogeneity problem with econometrics is to use our observational data in such a way that it behaves as though there were an experiment being run
Plenty of ways to do this weâ€™ll go over in this course!

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Concept Check

What does it mean to say that \(X\) has a causal effect on \(Y\)?
Why might the relationship between \(X\) and \(Y\) in data not be the same as the causal effect?
What is an example of observational data?
Consider the question of â€œDoes getting an MBA make you a better manager?â€ What are \(X\) and \(Y\) here? What would be in the error term \(\varepsilon\)? Are we likely to have an endogeneity problem here?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Spurious Correlations

Letâ€™s visit this site all about â€œspuriousâ€ correlations (i.e.Â correlations that almost certainly do not reveal a true effect of one variable on the other): https://tylervigen.com/spurious-correlations
Take a look at how easy it is to find variables that are related statistically, even though clearly neither causes the other
Do you think this correlation is an example of inferential error (just random chance) or identification error (truly related, but not because one causes the other)? Why?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Data Generating Process

Another example is a model of supply and demand
We observe prices and quantities in a competitive market
What led to those being the prices and quantities we see?
The supply and demand model and its equilibrium, we theorize!

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
\(X\) and \(Y\)

I have an \(X\) value of 2.5 and want to predict what \(Y\) will be. What can I do?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
\(X\) and \(Y\)

I canâ€™t just say â€œjust predict whatever values of \(Y\) we see for \(X = 2.5\), because there are multiple of those!
Plus, what if we want to predict for a value we DONâ€™T have any actual observations of, like \(X = 4.3\)?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Data is Granular

If I try to fit every point, Iâ€™ll get a mess that wonâ€™t really tell me the relationship between \(X\) and \(Y\)
So, we simplify the relationship into a shape: a line! The line smooths out those three points around 2.5 and fills in that gap around 4.3

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Isnâ€™t This Worse?

By adding a line, we are necessarily simplifying our presentation of the data. Weâ€™re tossing out information!
Our prediction of the data we have will be less accurate than if we just make predictions point-by-point
However, weâ€™ll do a better job predicting other data (avoiding â€œoverfittingâ€)
And, since a shape is something we can interpret, as opposed to a long list of predictions, which we canâ€™t really, the line will do a better job of telling us about the true underlying relationship

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
section: The Line Does a Few Things:
text:
The Line Does a Few Things:

We can get a prediction of \(Y\) for a given value of \(X\) (If we follow \(X = 2.5\) up to our line we get \(Y = 7.6\))
We see the relationship: the line slopes up, telling us that â€œmore \(X\) means more \(Y\) too!â€

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Lines

That line we get is the fit of our model
A model â€œfitâ€ means weâ€™ve taken a shape (our line) and picked the one that best fits our data
All forms of regression do this
Ordinary least squares specifically uses a straight line as its shape
The resulting line we get can also be written out as an actual line, i.e.

\[ Y = intercept + slope*X \]

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Lines

We can use that line asâ€¦ a line!
If we plug in a value of \(X\), we get a prediction for \(Y\)
Because these \(Y\) values are predictions, weâ€™ll give them a hat \(\hat{Y}\)

\[ Y = 3 + 4*X \]
\[ \hat{Y} = 3 + 4*(3.2) \]
\[ \hat{Y} = 15.8 \]

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Lines

We can also use it to explain the relationship
Whatever the intercept is, thatâ€™s what we predict for \(Y\) when \(X = 0\)

\[ Y = 3 + 4*X \]
\[ \hat{Y} = 3 + 4*0 \]
\[ \hat{Y} = 3 \]

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Lines

And as \(X\) increases, we know how much we expect \(Y\) to increase because of the slope

\[ Y = 3 + 4*X \]
\[ \hat{Y} = 3 + 4*3 = 15 \]
\[ \hat{Y} = 3 + 4*4 = 19 \]

When \(X\) increases by \(1\), \(Y\) increases by the slope (which is \(4\) here)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

Regression fits a shape to the data
Ordinary least squares specifically fits a straight line to the data
The straight line is described using an \(intercept\) and a \(slope\)
When we plug an \(X\) into the line, we get a prediction for \(Y\), which we call \(\hat{Y}\)
When \(X = 0\), we predict \(\hat{Y} = intercept\)
When \(X\) increases by \(1\), our prediction of \(Y\) increases by the \(slope\)
If \(slope > 0\), \(X\) and \(Y\) are positively related/correlated
If \(slope < 0\), \(X\) and \(Y\) are negatively related/correlated

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Concept Checks

How does producing a line let us use \(X\) to predict \(Y\)?
If our line is \(Y = 5 - 2*X\), explain what the \(-2\) means in a sentence
Not all of the points are exactly on the line, meaning some of our predictions will be wrong! Should we be concerned? Why or why not?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
How?

We know that regression fits a line
But how does it do that exactly?
It picks the line that produces the smallest squares
Thus, â€œordinary least squaresâ€

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Predictions and Residuals

Whenever you make a prediction of any kind, you rarely get it exactly right
The difference between your prediction and the actual data is the residual

\[ Y = 3 + 4*X \]
If we have a data point where \(X = 4\) and \(Y = 18\), then
\[ \hat{Y} = 3 + 4*4 = 19 \]
Then the residual is \(Y - \hat{Y} = 18 - 19 = -1\).

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Predictions and Residuals
So really, our relationship doesnâ€™t look like thisâ€¦
\[ Y = intercept + slope*X \]
Instead, itâ€™sâ€¦
\[ Y = intercept + slope*X + residual \]
We still use \(intercept + slope*X\) to predict \(Y\) though, so this is also
\[ Y = \hat{Y} + residual \]

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

As youâ€™d guess, a good prediction should make the residuals as small as possible
We want to pick a line to do that
And in particular, weâ€™re going to square those residuals, so the really-big residuals count even more. We really donâ€™t want to have points that are super far away from the line!
Then, we pick a line to minimize those squared residuals (â€œleast squaresâ€)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

Start with our data

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

Letâ€™s just pick a line at random, not necessarily from OLS

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

The vertical distance from point to line is the residual

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

Now square those residuals

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

Can we get the total area in the squares smaller with a different line?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

Ordinary Least Squares, I can promise you, gets it the smallest

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

How does it figure out which line makes the smallest squares?
Thereâ€™s a mathematical formula for that!
First, instead of thinking of \(intercept\) and \(slope\), we reframe the line as having parameters we can pick

\[ Y = intercept + slope*X + residual \]
\[ Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \varepsilon \]

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Fitting Lines
text:
Terminology Sidenote
\[ Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \varepsilon \]

In metrics, Greek letters represent â€œthe truthâ€ - in the true process by which the data is generated, a one-unit increase in \(X\) is related to a \(\beta_1\) increase in \(Y\)
When we put a hat on anything, that is our prediction or estimation of that true thing. \(\hat{Y}\) is our prediction of \(Y\), and \(\hat{\beta_1}\) is our estimate of what we think the true \(\beta_1\) is
Note â€œresidualâ€ =/= \(\varepsilon\) - residuals are whatâ€™s actually left over from our prediction with real data, but the error \(\varepsilon\) is the true difference between our line and \(Y\).

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 2 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Ordinary Least Squares

Now that we have our line in parametric terms, we can pick our estimates of \(\beta_0\) and \(\beta_1\) in order to make the squared residuals as small as possible
Pick \(\hat{\beta_0}\) and \(\hat{\beta_1}\) to minimize:

\[ \sum_i (residual_i^2) \]
\[ \sum_i ((Y_i - \hat{Y})^2) \]
\[ \sum_i ((Y_i - \hat{\beta_0} - \hat{\beta_1}X_i)^2) \]
Where the \(_i\) refers to a particular observation. \(\sum_i\) means â€œsum this up over all the observationsâ€
(Conveniently, you can pick \(\hat{\beta_0}\) and \(\hat{\beta_1}\) to minimize that expression with basic calculus)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Truth and Reality

Today weâ€™ll be covering hypothesis testing, which is one approach to using reality to get closer to the truth
It works by subtraction
We test whether certain versions of the truth are likely or unlikely
And if we find that theyâ€™re unlikely, we can reject that version of the truth, narrowing down what the actual possibilities are and getting closer and closer to the actual truth

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Truth and Reality

When weâ€™re talking about the truth here, weâ€™re referring to the true data generating process (DGP)
For example, if this is the true DGP:

\[ Wage_i = \beta_0 + \beta_1AdultHeight_i + \varepsilon_i \]
where \(cor(AdultHeight_i,\varepsilon_i) = 0\), thenâ€¦

Person \(i\)â€™s wage is truly determined by a linear function of your height, plus an unrelated error term \(\varepsilon_i\)
Why might someone have a high wage? Either theyâ€™re tall, or they have a high error term, or both. No other way!

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Truth and Reality

Our ability to estimate that true model depends on our ability to avoid inference and identification error
If we assume thatâ€™s the true DGP, thereâ€™s no endogeneity, and the relationship between \(Wage\) and \(AdultHeight\) is a straight line, so regular â€™ol OLS of \(Wage\) on \(AdultHeight\) will not give us identification error
But we also need to be careful about inference error
When we run that regression, what does our \(\hat{\beta}_1\) say about the true value \(\beta_1\)?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Sampling Variation

Notice that there is plenty of variation around the true value of \(2\)
Now letâ€™s imagine we donâ€™t know that and are trying to answer the question â€œis the truth \(\beta_1 = 2\)?â€
We donâ€™t have the full sampling distribution, we just have a single estimate:



(Intercept)           X 
   2.798554    2.215880 



All we see is \(\hat{\beta}_1 =\) 2.22. Soâ€¦ is \(\beta_1 = 2\)?

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Null Distribution

The â€œnull distributionâ€ is what the sampling distribution of the estimator would be if our null distribution were true
We can see that in the sampling distribution we have!
\(\beta_1 = 2\) is true, and hereâ€™s what the sampling distribution looks like! (although it would be smoother with more samples)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Null Distribution

So the key question that a hypothesis test asks is: given this null distribution, how unlikely is it that we get the result we get?
If itâ€™s super unlikely that the null is true and we get our result, wellâ€¦
We definitely got our resultâ€¦
So the null must be the part thatâ€™s wrong!
Thatâ€™s when we reject the null - we find that the sampling distribution under the null hardly ever produces a result like ours, so thatâ€™s probably the wrong sampling distribution and thus the wrong null!

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Null Distribution

How does this work out with our estimate of 2.22?
Letâ€™s stick it on the graph

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Hypothesis Test

Our test comes down to: how weird would it be to get a result this far from the â€œtruthâ€ or farther?
We can figure this out by shading in the parts of the null distribution this far from the null truth or farther
So we shade 2.22 and above, and also 2 - abs(2.22 - 2) = 1.78 and below.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Hypothesis Test

Based off of this sampling distribution, thereâ€™s a 31% + 26% = 57% chance of getting something as weird as we got or weirder (or for a one-tailed test, a 26% chance of getting something that high or higher) if the null of \(\beta_1 = 2\) is true
Thatâ€™s not too unlikely! So, we would fail to reject the null of \(\beta_1 = 2\)
This doesnâ€™t mean that we conclude that \(\beta_1 = 2\) is true, it just means we canâ€™t rule it out

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
The Null Distribution

Of course, we generated this null distribution by just randomly creating a few random samples
We also happen to know that if we had infinite samples, the sampling distribution of OLS would be a normal distribution with the mean at the true value and the standard deviation determined by \(var(X)\), the variance of the residual, and the sample size. The real null distribution looks like this:

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
The Null Distribution

So with the estimate we made from the sample we got (2.22), we canâ€™t reject a null \(\beta_1 = 2\)
Which is good!! Thatâ€™s the truth. We donâ€™t want to reject it!
How about other nulls? Can we reject those?
Can we reject a null that \(\beta_1 = 0\)?
(by default, most null hypotheses are that the parameter is 0)
Letâ€™s follow the same steps!

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
The Null Distribution

Now thatâ€™s unlikely. We can reject that the true value is 0.

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
p-values

The lower the p-value, the less likely it is that we got our result AND the null is true
And since we definitely got our result, a really low p-value says we should reject the null
How low does it need to be to reject the null?
Wellâ€¦

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
p-values and .05

Itâ€™s common practice to decide on a confidence level and a corresponding \(\alpha\), most commonly a 95% confidence level \(\rightarrow \alpha = .05\), and reject the null if the p-value is lower than \(\alpha\)
Why 95%? Completely arbitrary. Someone picked it out of thin air a hundred years ago as a just-for-instance and we still use it ğŸ¤·
Having a hard-and-fast threshold like this is not a great idea ( \(p=.04\) is rejection, but \(p=.06\) is not?), but itâ€™s a very hard habit to break
Key takeaway: get familiar with the concept of rejecting the null when the p-value is lower than .05, because youâ€™ll see it
BUT donâ€™t get too hung up on black-and-white rejection in general

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Power

Because the smaller we make our confidence level, the less likely we are to reject the null in general
Which means weâ€™ll also fail to reject it if itâ€™s actually false (a â€œfalse negativeâ€)
We want a low false-positive rate, but also a low false-negative rate
The false negative rate is called â€œpower.â€ If we will reject the null 80% of the time when itâ€™s actually false, we have 80% power
As \(\alpha\) shrinks, false-positive rates decline, but false-negative rates increase
Strike a balance!

(minor sidenote: â€œfalse positiveâ€ and â€œfalse negativeâ€ are sometimes referred to as â€œType I Errorâ€ and â€œType II Errorâ€ - these are not great terms because they are hard to remember! If you encounter them, just remember that in â€œThe boy who cried wolfâ€ the townspeople think thereâ€™s a wolf when thereâ€™s not, then think thereâ€™s not a wolf when there is, committing Type I and II error in that order)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
What we just didâ€¦

This is how we thought of it - we picked a null, figured out the null distribution (the sampling distribution of the estimator assuming the null was true), and checked if our estimate was unlikely enough that we could reject the null

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Insteadâ€¦

By thinking about standard errors, we instead center the sampling distribution around our estimate. If the null is far away, we reject that null (result should be the same)!

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Confidence Intervals

So what weâ€™re thinking now is not â€œis our estimate close to the null?â€ but rather â€œis that null close to our estimate?â€
We can go one step further and ask â€œwhich nulls are close to our estimate?â€ and figure out which nulls we can think about rejecting from there
A confidence interval shows the range of nulls that would not be rejected by our estimate
Everything outside that range can be rejected

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Confidence Intervals

This takes the form of

\[ \hat{\beta}_1 \pm Z(s.e.) \]

Where \(Z\) is some value from our distribution that gives us the \(1-\alpha\) percentile (for a 95% confidence interval with a normal sampling distribution, \(Z = 1.96\))
and \(s.e.\) is the standard error of \(\hat{\beta}_1\)

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Confidence Intervals

Thinking back to our estimate:







Model 1


(Intercept)
2.80Â 



(0.21)


X
2.22Â 



(0.37)


N
100Â Â Â Â 








Our estimate of the coefficient is 2.22, and our estimate of the standard error is 0.37
So for a 95% confidence interval, assuming normality, we get 2.22 \(\pm\) 1.96* 0.37, or [1.49,2.94]

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Confidence Intervals

We can see this graphically as well - we should only reject nulls in those 5% tails for a 95% confidence interval

title: ğŸ—“ï¸ Week 3 Hypothesis Testing
text:
Concept Checks

What feature of the sampling distribution of the \(\beta\) does the standard error describe?
Why do we get the same reject/donâ€™t reject result if we center the sampling distribution around the null as around our estimate?
We perform an estimate of \(\hat{\beta}_1\) and get a 95% confidence interval of [-1.3, 2.1]. Describe what this means in a sentence.
In the above confidence interval, can we reject the null of \(\beta_1 = 0\)?

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
The Right Hand Side
We will look at three features of the right-hand side

What if the variable is categorical or binary? (binary variables)
What if the variable has a nonlinear effect on \(Y\) (polynomials and logarithms)
What if the effect of one variable depends on the value of another variable? (interaction terms)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Comparison of Means

When a binary variable is an independent variable, what we are often interested in doing is comparing means
Is mean income higher inside the US or outside?
Is mean height higher for kids who got a nutrition supplement or those who didnâ€™t?
Is mean GDP growth higher with or without a floating exchange rate?

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Comparison of Means

Letâ€™s compare log earnings in 1993 between married people 30 or older vs.Â never-married people 30 or older
Seems to be a slight favor to the married men


data(PSID, package = 'Ecdat')
PSID <- PSID %>%
  filter(age >= 30, married %in% c('married','never married'), earnings > 0) %>%
  mutate(married  = married == 'married')
PSID %>%
  group_by(married) %>%
  summarize(log_earnings = mean(log(earnings)))

# A tibble: 2 Ã— 2
  married log_earnings
  <lgl>          <dbl>
1 FALSE           9.26
2 TRUE            9.47

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text: Comparison of Means

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Comparison of Means

The difference between the means follows a t-distribution under the null that theyâ€™re identical
So of course we can do a hypothesis test of whether theyâ€™re different
But why bother trotting out a specific test when we can just do a regression?
(In fact, a lot of specific tests can be replaced with basic regression, see this explainer)


feols(log(earnings) ~ married, data = PSID)

OLS estimation, Dep. Var.: log(earnings)

Standard-errors: IID

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Comparison of Means
Notice:

The intercept gives the mean for the non-married group
The coefficient on marriedTRUE gives the married minus non-married difference
The t-stat and p-value on that coefficient are exactly the same as that t.test (except the t is reversed; same deal)
i.e.Â the coefficient on a binary variable in a regression gives the difference in means
If weâ€™d defined it the other way, with â€œnot marriedâ€ as the independent variable, the intercept would be the mean for the married group (i.e.Â â€œnot married = 0â€), and the coefficient would be the exact same but times \(-1\) (same difference, just opposite direction!)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Comparison of Means
Why does OLS give us a comparison of means when you give it a binary variable?

The only \(X\) values are 0 (FALSE) and 1 (TRUE)
Because of this, OLS no longer really fits a line, itâ€™s more of two separate means
And when youâ€™re estimating to minimize the sum of squared errors separately for each group, canâ€™t do any better than to predict the mean!
So you get the mean of each group as each groupâ€™s prediction

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Binary with Controls

Obviously this is handy for including binary controls, but why do this for binary treatments? Because we can add controls!



                feols(log(earning..

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Multicollinearity

Why is just one side of it on the regression? Why arenâ€™t â€œmarriedâ€ and â€œnot marriedâ€ BOTH included?
Because regression couldnâ€™t give an answer!

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Multicollinearity

Mean of married is \(9.47\) and of non-married is \(9.26\). \[ \log(Earnings) = 0 + 9.47Married + 9.26NonMarried \] \[ \log(Earnings) = 3 + 6.47Married + 6.26NonMarried \]
These (and infinitely many other options) all give the exact same predictions! OLS canâ€™t pick between them. Thereâ€™s no single best way to minimize squared residuals
So we pick one with convenient properties, setting one of the categories to have a coefficient of 0 (dropping it) and making the coefficient on the other the difference relative to the one we left out

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
More than Two Categories

That interpretation - dropping one and making the other relative to that, conveniently extends to multi-category variables
Why stop at binary categorical variables? There are plenty of categorical variables with more than two values
What is your education level? What is your religious denomination? What continent are you on?
We can put these in a regression by turning each value into its own binary variable
(and then dropping one so the coefficients on the others give you the difference with the omitted one)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
More than Two Categories

Make the mean of group A be 1, of group B be 2, etc.


tib <- tibble(group = sample(LETTERS[1:4], 10000, replace = TRUE)) %>%
  mutate(Y = rnorm(10000) + (group == "A") + 2*(group == "B") + 3*(group == "C") + 4*(group == "D"))
feols(Y ~ group, data = tib)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
More than Two Categories

By changing the reference group, the coefficients change because theyâ€™re â€œdifferent fromâ€ a different group!
And notice that, as before, the intercept is the mean of the omitted group (although this changes once you add controls; the intercept is the predicted mean when all right-hand-side variables are 0)


tib <- tib %>% mutate(group = factor(group, levels = c('B','A','C','D')))
feols(Y ~ group, data = tib)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Concept Checks

If \(X\) is binary, in sentences interpret the coefficients from the estimated OLS equation \(Y = 4 + 3X + 2Z\)
How might a comparison of means come in handy if you wanted to analyze the results of a randomized policy experiment?
If you had a data set of people from every continent and added â€œcontinentâ€ as a control, how many coefficients would this add to your model?
If in that regression you really wanted to compare Europe to Asia specifically, what might you do so that the regression made this easy?

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interpreting OLS

To think more about the right-hand-side, letâ€™s go back to our original interpretation of an OLS coefficient \[ Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \varepsilon \]
A one-unit change in \(X\) is associated with a \(\beta_1\)-unit change in \(Y\)
This logic still works with binary variables since â€œa one-unit change in \(X\)â€ means â€œchanging \(X\) from No to Yesâ€
Notice that this assumes that a one-unit change in \(X\) always has the same effect on \(\beta_1\) no matter what else is going on
What if thatâ€™s not true?

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Functional Form

We talked before about times when a linear model like standard OLS might not be sufficient
However, as long as those non-linearities are on the right hand side, we can fix the problem easily but just having \(X\) enter non-linearly! Run it through a transformation!
The most common transformations by far are polynomials and logarithms

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Functional Form

Why do this? Because sometimes a straight line is clearly not going to do the trick!

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials

\(\beta_1X\) is a â€œfirst order polynomialâ€ - thereâ€™s one term
\(\beta_1X + \beta_2X^2\) is a â€œsecond order polynomialâ€ or a â€œquadraticâ€ - two terms (note both included, itâ€™s not just \(X^2\))
\(\beta_1X + \beta_2X^2 + \beta_3X^3\) is a third-order or cubic, etc.

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials
What do they do?

The more polynomial terms, the more flexible the line can be. With enough terms you can mimic any shape of relationship
Of course, if you just add a whole buncha terms, it gets very noisy, and prediction out-of-sample gets very bad
Keep it minimal - quadratics are almost always enough, unless you have reason to believe thereâ€™s a true more-complex relationship. You can try adding higher-order terms and see if they make a difference

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials

The true relationship is quadratic

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials

Higher-order terms donâ€™t do anything for us here (because a quadratic is sufficient!)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials in R

We can add an I() function to our regression to do a calculation on a variable before including it. So I(X^2) adds a squared term
Thereâ€™s also a poly() function but avoid it - it does something slightly different


# Linear
feols(Y ~ X, data = df)
# Quadratic
feols(Y ~ X + I(X^2), data = df)
# Cubic
feols(Y ~ X + I(X^2) + I(X^3), data = df)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Logarithms

Another common transformation, both for dependent and independent variables, is to take the logarithm
This has the effect of pulling in extreme values from strongly right-skewed data and making linear relationships pop out
Income, for example, is almost always used with a logarithm
It also gives the coefficients a nice percentage-based interpretation

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text: Logarithms

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Or if you preferâ€¦

Notice the change in axes

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Logarithms

How can we interpret them?
The key is to remember that \(\log(X) + a \approx \log((1+a)X)\), meaning that a \(a\)-unit change in \(log(X)\) is similar to a \(a\times100%\) change in \(X\)
So, walk through our â€œone-unit change in the variableâ€ logic from before, but whenever we hit a log, change that into a percentage!

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Logarithms

\(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1\log(X)\) A one-unit change in \(\log(X)\), or a 100% change in \(X\), is associated with a \(\beta_1\)-unit change in \(Y\)
\(\log(Y) = \beta_0 + \beta_1X\) a one-unit change in \(X\) is associated with a \(\beta_1\times 100\)% change in \(Y\)
\(\log(Y) = \beta_0 + \beta_1\log(X)\) A one-unit change in \(\log(X)\), or a or a 100% change in \(X\), is associated with a \(\beta_1\)-unit change in \(\log(Y)\), or a \(\beta_1\times100\)% change in \(Y\).
(Try also with changes smaller than one unit - thatâ€™s usually more reasonable)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Logarithms
Downsides:

Logarithms require that all data be positive. No negatives or zeroes!
Fairly rare that a variable with negative values wants a log anyway
But zeroes are common! A common practice is to just do \(log(X+1)\) but this is pretty arbitrary

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Functional Form

In general, you want the shape of your function to match the shape of the relationship in the data (or, even better, the true relationship)
Polynomials and logs can usually get you there!
Which to use? Use logs for highly skewed data or variables with exponential relationships
Use polynomials if it doesnâ€™t look straight! Check that scatterplot and see how not-straight it is!

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Concept Checks

Which of the following variables would you likely want to log before using them? Income, height, wealth, company size, home square footage
In each of the following estimated OLS lines, interpret the coefficient by filling in â€œA [blank] change in X is associated with a [blank] change in Yâ€:

\[ Y = 1 + 2\log(X) \] \[ \log(Y) = 3 + 2\log(X) \]
\[ \log(Y) = 4 + 3X \]

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interactions

For both polynomials and logarithms, the effect of a one-unit change in \(X\) differs depending on its current value (for logarithms, a 1-unit change in \(X\) is different percentage changes in \(X\) depending on current value)
But why stop there? Maybe the effect of \(X\) differs depending on the current value of other variables!
Enter interaction terms!

\[ Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \beta_2Z + \beta_3X\times Z + \varepsilon \] - Interaction terms are a little tough but also extremely important.

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interactions
Expect to come back to these slides, as youâ€™re almost certainly going to use interaction terms in both our assessment and the dissertation

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interactions

Change in the value of a control can shift a regression line up and down
Using the model \(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \beta_2Z\), estimated as \(Y = .01 + 1.2X + .95Z\):

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interactions

But an interaction can both shift the line up and down AND change its slope
Using the model \(Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \beta_2Z + \beta_3X\times Z\), estimated as \(Y = .035 + 1.14X + .94Z + 1.02X\times Z\):

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interactions

How can we interpret an interaction?
The idea is that the interaction shows how the effect of one variable changes as the value of the other changes
The derivative helps!

\[ Y = \beta_0 + \beta_1X + \beta_2Z + \beta_3X\times Z \] \[ \partial Y/\partial X = \beta_1 + \beta_3 Z \]

The effect of \(X\) is \(\beta_1\) when \(Z = 0\), or \(\beta_1 + \beta_3\) when \(Z = 1\), or \(\beta_1 + 3\beta_3\) if \(Z = 3\)!

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interactions

Often we are doing interactions with binary variables to see how an effect differs across groups
Now, instead of the intercept giving the baseline and the binary coefficient giving the difference, the coefficient on \(X\) is the baseline effect of \(X\) and the interaction is the difference in the effect of \(X\)
The interaction coefficient becomes â€œthe difference in the effect of \(X\) between the \(Z\) =â€Noâ€ and \(Z\) = â€œYesâ€ groupsâ€
(What if itâ€™s continuous? Mathematically the same but the thinking changes - the interaction term is the difference in the effect of \(X\) you get when increasing \(Z\) by one unit)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Notes on Interactions

Like with polynomials, the coefficients on their own now have little meaning and must be evaluated alongside each other. \(\beta_1\) by itself is just â€œthe effect of \(X\) when \(Z = 0\)â€, not â€œthe effect of \(X\)â€
Yes, you do almost always want to include both variables in un-interacted form and interacted form. Otherwise the interpretation gets very thorny

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
In R!

Binary variables in R (on the right-hand-side) you can just treat as normal variables
Categorical variables too (although if itâ€™s numeric you may need to run it through factor() first, or i() in feols())
In feols() you can specify which group gets dropped using i() and setting ref in it


# drops married = FALSE
feols(log(earnings) ~ married, data = PSID)
# drops married = TRUE
feols(log(earnings) ~ i(married, ref = 'TRUE'), data = PSID)

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials and Logarithms

As previously discussed, \(I()\) will let us do functions like \(X^2\)
We can also do log() straight in the regression.


lm(Y ~ X + I(X^2) + I(X^3), data = df)
lm(log(Y) ~ log(X), data = df)

text:
Interactions

Marriage for those without a college degree raises earnings by 24%. A college degree reduces the marriage premium by 25%. Marriage for those with a college degree reduces earnings by .24 - .25 = -1%

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Tests

wald() can be handy for testing groups of binary variables for a categorical
Also good for testing all the polynomial terms, or testing if the effect of \(X\) is significant at a certain value of \(Z\)


# Is the education effect zero overall?
m1 <- feols(log(earnings)~educatn, data = PSID)
wald(m1, 'educatn')

# Does X have any effect?
m2 <- feols(Y ~ X + I(X^2) + I(X^3), data = df)
wald(m2, 'X') # Gets all coefficients with an 'X' anywhere in the name - check this is right!

# Is the effect of X significant when Z = 5?
library(multcomp)
m3 <- lm(Y ~ X*Z, data = df)
glht(m3, 'X + 5*X:Z= 0') %>% summary()




PB4A7- Quantitative Applications for Behavioural Science

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials

Interpret polynomials using the derivative
\(\partial Y/\partial X\) will be different depending on the value of \(X\) (as it should! Notice in the graph that the slope changes for different values of \(X\))

\[ Y = \beta_1X + \beta_2X^2 \] \[ \partial Y/\partial X = \beta_1 + 2\beta_2X \]
So at \(X = 0\), the effect of a one-unit change in \(X\) is \(\beta_1\). At \(X = 1\), itâ€™s \(\beta_1 + \beta_2\). At \(X = 5\) itâ€™s \(\beta_1 + 5\beta_2\).

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Polynomials

IMPORTANT: when you have a polynomial, the coefficients on each individual term mean very little on their own. You have to consider them alongisde the other coefficients from the polynomial! Never interpret \(\beta_1\) here without thinking about \(\beta_2\) alongside. Also, the significance of the individual terms doesnâ€™t really matter - consider doing an F-test of all of them at once.

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Interactions

X*Z will include X, Z, and also their interaction
If necessary, X:Z is the interaction only, but you rarely need this. However, itâ€™s handy for referring to the interaction term in linearHypothesis!
In feols() the i() function is a very powerful way of doing interactions


feols(Y ~ X*Z, data = df)
feols(Y ~ X + X:Z, data = df)
feols(Y ~ i(Z, X), data = df)
feols(Y ~ i(Z, X), data = df) |> iplot()

title: Binary Variables and Functional Form
text:
Notes on Interactions

Interaction effects are poorly powered. You need a lot of data to be able to tell whether an effect is different in two groups. If \(N\) observations is adequate power to see if the effect itself is different from zero, you need a sample of roughly \(16\times N\) to see if the difference in effects is nonzero. Sixteen times!!
Itâ€™s tempting to try interacting your effect with everything to see if itâ€™s bigger/smaller/nonzero in some groups, but because itâ€™s poorly powered, this is a bad idea! Youâ€™ll get a lot of false positives
